instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
Board had small corrosion on a couple caps and keyboard connector, got all that cleaned and fixed, but still same behaivior.

<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH are heating up while the board tries to startup.

smc bypass doesn't seem to do anything

Board sits around 70-80ma 

ppbus 12.6v 
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
If the board only tries to start, no way to heats the chips so fast.
Unless it takes some time "trying to start".
What about <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS and RTC voltage?
Any S3/0 voltage tries to appear?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
It takes a few seconds for the chips to heat up.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_REG_R</SIGNAL> 1.05v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
So you also get S0 voltages.
Post all the volatges you have and specify if go off in time, or stable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
This board now has a new SMC and clean BIOS, with those 2 things the behavior is the exact same.

At 12 seconds they all go off then come back and stay steady after that with their respective voltage.

Board stays around ~0.065a steady after a few seconds.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP0V675_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
Did you try known good BIOS posted on the forum?
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
I just tried the BIOS from here: [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-efi-serial-number-issue.59145/#post-59146[/URL]

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 0v

Still same behavior

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message: If board stays on and VCORE present, check <SIGNAL>PM_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
Could no find <SIGNAL>PM_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> but found <SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>  is 3.4v
<SIGNAL>VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  is 1v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
Looks like PCH issue; heat it with quality flux.
May have luck and could be only crap accumulated underneath...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
OK so in this board the PCH is integrated on the CPU, should I use the zaomao for this? 

If not just put good flux and heat with how air?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and PCH heating up
threads.message:
NO, you don't need to melt the balls.
180-200 degrees is more than enough to burn eventual crap.
Use only hot air station...
